text: It's been 11 years now,
March 4th 2009.
The date you go in and the date you come
home, you'll never forget those days.
The day I was arrested was the day I
found out I was like four weeks pregnant.
You think your life's over and then
someone tells you you're pregnant and
it's just kind of,
it's a lot, but it's the best thing that
could have ever happened to me.
All of it.
[Music]
Coming home, it's
just a crazy reality.
You've been constricted to this small
area for such a long time
constantly kind of being told and
through the messaging
of the system that you're less than, and
it's really difficult to separate from
that. I'm Aedan Macdonald and I'm the
founder
and program manager of Justice Through
Code. Justice Through Code
is the semester-long coding and
interpersonal skills intensive
for the formerly incarcerated. I think
it's really telling
to think about the statistics. About four
years after release from incarceration
75 percent of people will be re-arrested.
The single most important predictor
of recidivism is unemployment, but yet
people can't get jobs.
It's very difficult just completely
starting over.
The excitement of being free,
but then the reality of
not being prepared.
That things had changed rapidly in
just the few short years that I was away
and
when you're incarcerated everything is
stripped from you, like
you're no longer who you are and then
when you come home
you're trying to be just, even just be a
person again.
I mean, I can speak to my personal
experience. I was incarcerated
in federal prison for close to four
years. When I returned
home I went to a halfway house in
Connecticut.
And for me it was very difficult
to get a job. A year after release from
incarceration
75 percent of people will be unemployed.
When you look at that and think about
the statistics,
that for the bottom 10 percent
of earners in this country their
children
are approximately 20 times more likely
to end up incarcerated
in their lifetimes than the top 10
percent of earners.
Not only is it impossible to get a job,
in many ways because of the way that we
treat people that have returned home
from prison
these young children don't have a chance
as well.
There's definitely a fear, like all right
so now I'm coming out of prison who's
gonna hire me?
I remember looking up different careers
and
all of these requirements like how am I
going to take care of this
little girl that I fought for, like how
am I going to be able to provide her the
life that she deserves?
Someone told me about the Justice
Through Code coding program and I didn't
have experience, but I always wanted to
learn it, but it was just kind of like
a big overwhelming thing like where do
you even start?
